newsitem.title: GERMANY: German rapeseed crop to date shows mixed results.
newsitem.headline: German rapeseed crop to date shows mixed results.

text.p: Rapeseed harvests in Germany continued amid regional rainfall, producing yields generally below last year's 3.2 tonnes a hectare, farm and trade sources said on Thursday.
Some 50 to 90 percent had been harvested, with slower progress seen in Schleswig-Holstein in the north and with just one third harvested in eastern German states.
Yields in the north ranged from one t/ha in fields which suffered winter damage to 3.5 t/ha or better in others.
Moisture levels were between nine and 13 percent -- with eight percent the target -- while oil content was mostly fair above 40 percent.
Bavarian farmers in the south reported lower volumes which were snapped up by the trade, but crushers did not respond to the trend as weak oil business discouraged buying.
Regional yields were around 2.0-2.5 t/ha, with oil content at 40-42 percent and moisture at 12-16 percent.
National ex-farm rapeseed prices were in a 380-420 marks a tonne range, according to price statistics office ZMP.
Farmers and traders were aiming for higher prices on the strength of high moisture and weed levels and uneven ripening which they said caused extra costs.
Crushers were reluctant to agree mill delivered prices which were roughly 30-70 marks above the farmgate level, boosted by producer and trade retention.
They also pointed to weak oil and meal business and the possibility of replacind rape with soya.
The farm ministry at a press conference on August 29 is expected to issue preliminary rapeseed harvest results.
